  "user-to-convert"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_BLOB
tools.title: Create a blob
tools.description: Creates a Git blob in a repository, requiring content and encoding ('utf-8' or 'base64').

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the '.git' extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
Example: "Hello-World"

owner.description:
The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

content.description:
The content to be stored in the new blob.
Examples:
  "This is the raw content of the file."
  "SGVsbG8gV29ybGQ=\\n"

encoding.description:
The encoding for the 'content'; "utf-8" or "base64".
Examples:
  "utf-8"
  "base64"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_CHECK_RUN
tools.title: Create a check run
tools.description: Creates a new check run for a specific commit in a repository, used by external services to report status, detailed feedback, annotations, and images directly within the GitHub UI.

name.description:
The name of the check to be displayed in the GitHub UI. For example, "Code Coverage" or "Linter".
Example: "mighty_linter"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case sensitive.
Example: "Hello-World"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. This name is not case sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

status.description: The current status of the check run. Only GitHub Actions can set `status` to `waiting`, `pending`, or `requested`.

label.description: The text to be displayed on a button in the web UI (max 20 characters).

identifier.description: A reference for the action on the integrator's system (max 20 characters).

description.description: A short explanation of what this action would do (max 40 characters).

items.description: Model for a check run action.

actions.description: A list of up to three action objects defining interactive buttons displayed on GitHub after the check run completes. Each object needs a `label` (button text), `identifier` (unique ID for the action), and `description` (tooltip). Clicking a button sends a `check_run.requested_action` webhook to your app.

head_sha.description:
The SHA of the commit for which the check run is created.
Example: "009b8392b1d19195ab1750317ce01ed503788888"

conclusion.description: **Required if `completed_at` is provided or if `status` is `completed`**. Specifies the final outcome of the check (e.g., 'success', 'failure'). Note: Setting `conclusion` automatically sets `status` to `completed`. GitHub alone can set a conclusion to `stale`.

started_at.description:
The ISO 8601 timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ) indicating when the check run began.
Example: "2018-05-04T01:14:52Z"

details_url.description:
The URL of the integrator's site providing full details of the check. If omitted, the GitHub App's homepage is used. This URL is available from the check's UI.
Example: "https://example.com/build/status"

external_id.description:
A unique identifier for the check run on the integrator's system. This helps in correlating check runs between GitHub and the external system.
Example: "42"

completed_at.description:
The ISO 8601 timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ) indicating when the check run finished. **Required if `status` is `completed`**.
Example: "2018-05-04T01:14:52Z"

output__text.description: Detailed textual information about the check run's output. Supports Markdown. **Maximum length**: 65,535 characters.

output__title.description:
A descriptive title for the output of the check run, displayed in the GitHub UI. For example, 'Linter Scan Summary'.
Example: "Linter Scan Summary"

alt.description: The alternative text for the image.

image_url.description: The full URL of the image.

items.description: Model for a check run image.

output__images.description: A list of image objects to display in the check run's output in the GitHub UI. Each object requires `alt` (alternative text), `image_url` (URL of the image), and an optional `caption`.

output__summary.description:
A summary of the check run's findings. Supports Markdown. **Maximum length**: 65,535 characters.
Example: "Found 2 critical issues and 5 warnings."

path.description: The path of the file to add an annotation to.

title.description: The title that represents the annotation.

message.description: A short description of the feedback for these lines of code.

end_line.description: The end line of the annotation.

end_column.description: The end column of the annotation. Annotations only support start_column and end_column on the same line.

start_line.description: The start line of the annotation.

start_column.description: The start column of the annotation. Annotations only support start_column and end_column on the same line.

annotation_level.description: The level of the annotation (notice, warning, or failure).

items.description: Model for a check run annotation.

output__annotations.description: A list of annotation objects detailing issues at specific code locations. Annotations are visible in the 'Checks' and 'Files changed' tabs of a pull request. Each annotation object should specify `path`, `start_line`, `end_line`, `annotation_level` ('notice', 'warning', or 'failure'), and `message`. Optional fields include `start_column`, `end_column`, `title`, and `raw_details`. Up to 50 annotations per API request; for more, use subsequent 'Update a check run' calls. GitHub Actions limits are 10 warnings and 10 errors per step.

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_CHECK_SUITE
tools.title: Create a check suite
tools.description: Creates a new check suite for a specific commit (`head_sha`) in an original repository (not a fork); GitHub dispatches a `check_suite` webhook event with the `requested` action upon success.

repo.description:
Repository name, without the `.git` extension (case-insensitive).
Example: "Hello-World"

owner.description:
Account owner of the repository (case-insensitive).
Example: "octocat"

head_sha.description:
SHA of the commit for which to create the check suite, typically the head commit of a branch.
Example: "7638417db6d59f3c431d3e1f261cc637155684cd"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_CODESPACE_FOR_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER
tools.title: Create a codespace for the authenticated user

annotations.title: Create a codespace for the authenticated user

tools.description: Creates a GitHub Codespace for the authenticated user, requiring a JSON request body with either `repository_id` (integer) or a `pull_request` object (containing `pull_request_number` (integer) and `repository_id` (integer)). This action allows users to set up a development environment quickly by creating a codespace from a specified repository or pull request.

ref.description:
Git ref (branch, tag, or commit SHA) to use for the codespace.
Examples:
  "main"
  "refs/heads/main"
  "a1b2c3d"

repository_id.description: Repository ID for the pull request.
ID of the repository to create the codespace from.

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_CODESPACE_FROM_A_PULL_REQUEST
tools.title: Create a codespace from a pull request

annotations.title: Create a codespace from a pull request

tools.description: Creates a GitHub Codespace for an open pull request in a Codespaces-enabled repository, with options to customize its configuration.

geo.description:
Geographic area for this codespace (e.g., `UsEast`, `EuropeWest`); supersedes `location`. If unspecified, typically IP-derived.
Examples:
  "UsEast"
  "EuropeWest"
  "SoutheastAsia"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This is case-insensitive.
Example: "Spoon-Knife"

owner.description:
The username of the account that owns the repository. This is case-insensitive.
Example: "octocat"

machine.description:
Machine type for this codespace (e.g., `standardLinux`). Varies by CPU, RAM, storage. Uses default if unspecified.
Examples:
  "standardLinux"
  "standardLinux8gb"
  "standardLinux16gb"
  "standardLinux32gb"

location.description:
Requested geographic location (e.g., `EastUs`, `WestEurope`). This parameter is deprecated; use `geo`. If unspecified, location may be IP-derived.
Examples:
  "EastUs"
  "WestEurope"

client_ip.description:
Client's public IP address for location auto-detection if proxied and `geo` or `location` are not specified.
Example: "192.0.2.1"

pull_number.description:
The unique number identifying the pull request.
Example: 1347

display_name.description:
Custom name for the codespace.
Example: "My Feature Branch Codespace"

devcontainer_path.description:
Path to a `devcontainer.json` file in the repository that defines the development environment.
Examples:
  ".devcontainer/devcontainer.json"
  "devcontainer.json"

working_directory.description:
Working directory for the codespace upon opening. Defaults to the repository root if unspecified.
Example: "/workspaces/my-project/src"

idle_timeout_minutes.description:
Minutes of inactivity after which the codespace is automatically stopped. A default timeout applies if unspecified.
Examples:
  30
  60

retention_period_minutes.description:
Retention period in minutes (0-43200, i.e., up to 30 days) for a stopped codespace. 0 means immediate deletion.
Examples:
  1440
  43200

multi_repo_permissions_opt_out.description: Set to `true` to prevent GitHub from requesting additional repository permissions defined in `devcontainer.json`. Defaults to `false` (permissions will be requested).

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_CODESPACE_IN_A_REPOSITORY
tools.title: Create a codespace in a repository

annotations.title: Create a codespace in a repository

tools.description: Creates a GitHub Codespace for the authenticated user in a specified repository, which must be accessible and use a valid `devcontainer.json` if `devcontainer_path` is specified.

geo.description:
Geographic area for the codespace, replacing `location`; determined by user IP if not specified.
Examples:
  "EuropeWest"
  "SoutheastAsia"
  "UsEast"
  "UsWest"

ref.description:
Git reference (e.g., branch name) for the codespace; uses repository's default branch if not provided.
Examples:
  "main"
  "feature-branch-name"

repo.description:
Name of the repository, without the `.git` extension; not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "Spoon-Knife"
  "vscode"

owner.description:
Username or organization name owning the repository; not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "Microsoft"

machine.description:
Machine type (CPU, RAM, storage). See 'List available machine types for a repository' action for options; uses a default type if not specified.
Examples:
  "standardLinux"
  "premiumLinux"

location.description:
Requested AWS region (best-effort, may differ); determined by user IP if not provided. Deprecated: use `geo`.
Examples:
  "EastUs"
  "WestUs"
  "WestEurope"
  "SoutheastAsia"

client_ip.description:
IP address to infer preferred region if `location` and `geo` are unspecified; useful for proxied requests.
Example: "192.168.1.100"

display_name.description:
Custom display name for the codespace; a default name is generated if not provided.
Example: "My Development Codespace"

devcontainer_path.description:
Path to a `devcontainer.json` in the repository; uses `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` or `devcontainer.json` at root if not specified.
Example: ".devcontainer/my-custom-devcontainer.json"

working_directory.description:
Directory to use as default when codespace opens; uses repository root if not specified.
Example: "/projects/my-app"

idle_timeout_minutes.description:
Minutes of inactivity before codespace auto-stops; uses a default timeout if not specified.
Examples:
  30
  60

retention_period_minutes.description:
Minutes an idle (stopped) codespace is retained before auto-deletion (0-43200, i.e., up to 30 days); uses a default period if not specified.
Examples:
  1440
  43200

multi_repo_permissions_opt_out.description:
If `true`, opts out of granting multi-repository permissions from `devcontainer.json`. If unspecified or `false`, permissions are granted if requested.
Examples:
  true
  false

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_COMMIT
tools.title: Create a commit
tools.description: Creates a new commit in a GitHub repository; the `tree` SHA and any `parents` SHAs must already exist in the repository.

repo.description:
Name of the repository, without the `.git` extension (case-insensitive).
Example: "Spoon-Knife"

tree.description:
SHA of the tree object for this commit; must exist in the repository.
Example: "9c1a209e10072fe99393945673ace821a4827669"

owner.description:
Account owner of the repository (case-insensitive).
Example: "octocat"

message.description:
The commit message.
Example: "feat: implement user authentication endpoint"

parents.description:
SHAs of parent commits; all must exist in the repository. Omit or provide an empty list for a root commit.
Examples:
  "[\"1a2b3c4d5e6f7g8h9i0jabcdef1234567890\"]"
  "[\"parent_sha_main\", \"parent_sha_feature_branch\"]"

signature.description:
ASCII-armored detached PGP signature over the commit data. GitHub adds this to the `gpgsig` header if provided.
Example: "-----BEGIN PGP SIGNATURE-----\\n...\\n-----END PGP SIGNATURE-----"

author__date.description:
Timestamp (ISO 8601: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`) when the commit was authored.
Example: "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z"

author__name.description:
Name of the commit's author. Defaults to authenticated user if not provided.
Example: "Mona Lisa Octocat"

author__email.description:
Email of the commit's author. Defaults to authenticated user if not provided.
Example: "mona@example.com"

committer__date.description:
Timestamp (ISO 8601: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`) when the commit was committed. Defaults to `author_date` or current time.
Example: "2024-01-15T10:35:00Z"

committer__name.description:
Name of the committer. Defaults to author's name or authenticated user if not provided.
Example: "The Octocat"

committer__email.description:
Email of the committer. Defaults to author's email or authenticated user if not provided.
Example: "octocat@example.com"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_COMMIT_COMMENT
tools.title: Create a commit comment
tools.description: Creates a comment on a specific commit, or on a specific line if `path` and `position` are provided.

body.description:
The text content of the comment.
Examples:
  "This is a great commit!"
  "LGTM :+1:"

line.description:
**Deprecated:** Use `position` instead. Line number in the file to comment on. `position` takes precedence if both are provided.
Examples:
  "5"
  "23"

path.description:
Relative path of the file to comment on. If specified, `position` is also required.
Examples:
  "src/main.py"
  "docs/README.md"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension.
Examples:
  "Spoon-Knife"
  "my-project"

owner.description:
The username or organization name that owns the repository.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github"

position.description:
Line number in the diff's patch to comment on, relative to the commit's changes. Required if `path` is specified.
Examples:
  "1"
  "15"

commit_sha.description:
The SHA identifier of the commit to comment on.
Example: "a1b2c3d4e5f6a7b8c9d0e1f2a3b4c5d6e7f8a9b0"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_COMMIT_STATUS
tools.title: Create a commit status
tools.description: Sets a commit's status (e.g., error, failure, pending, success from CI/CD) for a given SHA; max 1000 statuses per SHA/context.

sha.description:
SHA hash of the commit.
Examples:
  "c5b97d5ae6c19d5c5df71a34c7fbeeda2479ccbc"
  "6dcb09b5b57875f334f61aebed695e2e4193db5e"

repo.description:
Repository name, without the `.git` extension (case-insensitive).
Examples:
  "Hello-World"
  "Spoon-Knife"

owner.description:
Username or organization name of the repository owner (case-insensitive).
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github"

state.description:
State of the commit status, indicating check outcome or phase.
Examples:
  "error"
  "failure"
  "pending"
  "success"

context.description:
Label to differentiate this status from other systems (e.g., 'ci/jenkins'); case-insensitive.
Examples:
  "ci/jenkins"
  "linter/eslint"
  "default"

target_url.description:
URL linking to the source of the status (e.g., CI build log), displayed in GitHub UI.
Examples:
  "http://ci.example.com/user/repo/build/sha"
  "https://example.com/deployment/status/123"

description.description:
Human-readable description of the status, displayed in GitHub UI.
Examples:
  "Build successful"
  "Tests passed with 0 failures"
  "Deployment to staging failed"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_CUSTOM_ORGANIZATION_ROLE
tools.title: Create a custom organization role
tools.description: Creates a custom role with defined permissions within a GitHub organization.

org.description:
Name of the GitHub organization (case-insensitive) where the custom role will be created.
Examples:
  "github"
  "my-company-org"

name.description:
Unique name for the custom role.
Examples:
  "Triage Access"
  "Security Auditor"
  "Release Manager"

description.description:
Optional short description of the custom role's purpose or permissions.
Examples:
  "Grants read-only access to organization settings and member audit logs."
  "Allows managing repository security advisories."

permissions.description:
List of permission strings defining actions granted by this role; see GitHub docs for available permissions.
Examples:
  "read:org"
  "manage_runners:org"
  "create_repository"
  "administer_repository"
  "delete_issues"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_DEPLOY_KEY
tools.title: Create a deploy key
tools.description: Creates a deploy key for a repository; the repository must exist and be accessible, and the provided key must be a valid public SSH key.

key.description:
The full public SSH key. Ensure this is the public key, not the private key.
Example: "ssh-rsa AAAAB3NzaC1yc2EAAAADAQABAAABAQC... user@example.com"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This is not case sensitive.
Example: "Hello-World"

owner.description:
The username of the account that owns the repository. This is not case sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

title.description:
A descriptive name for the new deploy key. If not provided, a default name will be generated.
Example: "Staging Server Key"

read_only.description:
If `true`, the deploy key will only have read access. If `false` (default), the key will have read and write access. Write access grants significant privileges.
Examples:
  true
  false

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_DEPLOYMENT
tools.title: Create a deployment
tools.description: Creates a GitHub deployment for an existing repository, targeting a specific ref (branch, tag, or SHA) that must also exist within the repository.

ref.description:
The ref to deploy. This can be a branch name, a tag name, or a commit SHA.
Examples:
  "main"
  "v1.2.3"
  "c0ff335h4c0d3f0r3x4mpl3"

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.

task.description:
Specifies a task to execute, e.g., `deploy` or `deploy:migrations`.
Examples:
  "deploy"
  "deploy:migrations"
  "build_and_deploy"

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This name is not case-sensitive.

payload.description:
A JSON string payload providing additional information that a deployment system might need, customizable based on the deployment process.
Examples:
  "'''{\"deploy_tool\": \"custom_script\", \"target_environment\": \"server_alpha\"}'''"
  "'''{\"user_initiating\": \"admin_user\"}'''"

auto_merge.description: Attempts to automatically merge the default branch into the requested ref if the ref is behind the default branch. Set to `false` to disable.

description.description:
A short description of the deployment. Maximum length of 1000 characters.
Examples:
  "Deploying new feature X to staging."
  "Hotfix for critical bug #123."

environment.description:
Name for the target deployment environment (e.g., `production`, `staging`, `qa`).
Examples:
  "production"
  "staging"
  "develop"
  "qa"

required_contexts.description:
A list of status check contexts to verify against commit status checks before creating the deployment. If omitted or `null`, GitHub verifies all unique contexts. Pass an empty list `[]` to bypass all checks.
Examples:
  ["continuous-integration/jenkins","security/snyk"]
  []

transient_environment.description: Specifies if the given environment is specific to this deployment and will no longer exist at some point in the future (e.g., a staging environment for a pull request). Set to `true` if the environment is temporary.

production_environment.description: Specifies if the given environment is one that end-users directly interact with.

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_DEPLOYMENT_BRANCH_POLICY
tools.title: Create a deployment branch policy
tools.description: Creates a deployment branch or tag policy for an existing environment in a GitHub repository, using a Ruby File.fnmatch pattern (where `*` doesn't match `/`) to specify which branches or tags are deployable.

name.description:
Name pattern for deployable branches/tags (Ruby File.fnmatch syntax; `*` won't match `/`, e.g., `release/*/*` for `release/feature/login`). Refer to [Ruby File.fnmatch documentation](https://ruby-doc.org/core-2.5.1/File.html#method-c-fnmatch).
Examples:
  "main"
  "releases/*"
  "feature/user-*"
  "v*.*.*"

repo.description:
Name of the repository, without the `.git` extension (not case sensitive).
Examples:
  "hello-world"
  "my-app-repository"

type.description:
Whether the policy targets a Git branch or a tag.
Examples:
  "branch"
  "tag"

owner.description:
Account owner of the repository (not case sensitive).
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "my-organization"

environment_name.description:
Name of the target environment; URL-encode special characters (e.g., `/` as `%2F`).
Examples:
  "production"
  "staging%2Ffrontend"
  "development_v2"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_DEPLOYMENT_STATUS
tools.title: Create a deployment status
tools.description: Creates a status for an existing deployment, updating its operational state, associated URLs, and description.

repo.description:
The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.
Example: "hello-world"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

state.description:
State of the status. Setting a transient deployment to `inactive` shows it as `destroyed` in GitHub.
Examples:
  "success"
  "pending"
  "failure"

log_url.description:
URL for deployment output. Preferred over `target_url`; setting this also sets `target_url` to the same value.
Example: "https://ci.example.com/job/my-app/15/console"

target_url.description:
URL for deployment status updates or output. `log_url` is generally preferred.
Example: "https://example.com/deployment/output/123"

description.description:
Short description of the status (max 140 characters).
Example: "Deployment to staging completed successfully."

environment.description:
Name for the target deployment environment (e.g., `production`, `staging`). If unset, uses environment from previous status or deployment.
Examples:
  "production"
  "staging"

auto_inactive.description:
If true, sets prior successful, non-transient, non-production deployments in the same repository and environment to `inactive`.
Examples:
  "true"
  "false"

deployment_id.description:
The unique identifier of the deployment for which to create a status.
Example: 12345

environment_url.description:
URL for accessing the target deployment environment.
Example: "https://myapp-staging.example.com"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_DISCUSSION
tools.title: Create a discussion
tools.description: Creates a new discussion post on a specific team's page within an organization.

org.description:
Name of the organization (not case-sensitive).
Example: "my-github-org"

body.description:
Main content of the discussion post, typically in markdown.
Examples:
  "Let'''s brainstorm ideas for the upcoming hackathon."
  "Please review the attached document regarding the new API."

title.description:
Title of the discussion post.
Examples:
  "New Q3 Project Proposals"
  "Team Offsite Ideas"

private.description:
If `true`, post is private (visible only to team members, org owners, and team maintainers); `false` makes it public to all organization members.
Examples:
  "true"
  "false"

team_slug.description:
URL-friendly version of the team name (slug).
Examples:
  "engineering-team"
  "marketing-mavens"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_DISCUSSION_COMMENT
tools.title: Create a discussion comment
tools.description: Creates a new comment on an existing team discussion within a GitHub organization.

org.description:
The name of the organization. This name is not case-sensitive.
Example: "octo-org"

body.description:
The content of the discussion comment. Supports GitHub Flavored Markdown.
Example: "Great point! I agree with this approach."

team_slug.description:
The slug (URL-friendly version) of the team name.
Example: "justice-league"

discussion_number.description:
The unique number identifying the discussion within the team.
Example: "42"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_FORK
tools.title: Create a fork
tools.description: Creates a fork of an accessible repository, optionally into a specific organization, with a new name, or copying only the default branch.

name.description:
The desired name for the newly created fork. If not provided, the new fork will have the same name as the original repository.
Example: "my-awesome-fork"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case sensitive.
Example: "Spoon-Knife"

owner.description:
The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

organization.description:
The GitHub organization name to fork the repository into. If not specified, the fork will be created in the authenticated user's account.
Example: "my-github-org"

default_branch_only.description:
Specifies whether to fork only the default branch of the repository. If `True`, only the default branch is copied. If `False` or not specified, all branches are copied.
Example: true

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_GIST
tools.title: Create a gist
tools.description: Creates a new gist on GitHub with provided files, an optional description, and public/secret visibility.

files.description:
JSON string representing content for the gist's files. Dictionary where keys are filenames and values are objects, each having a `content` key with the file's raw string data.
Examples:
  "{\"hello_world.txt\": {\"content\": \"Hello, Universe!\"}}"
  "{\"main.py\": {\"content\": \"def main():\\n    print(\\\"Executed\\\")\\nif __name__ == \\\"__main__\\\":\\n    main()\"}, \"README.md\": {\"content\": \"# My Gist\\nThis is a test gist.\"}}"

public.description:
Indicates if the gist is public (`true`) or secret (`false`).
Examples:
  "true"
  "false"

description.description:
Optional description for the gist.
Examples:
  "My new Python utility functions"
  "Example of API usage"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_GIST_COMMENT
tools.title: Create a gist comment
tools.description: Creates a new comment on a specified GitHub gist.

body.description:
The text of the comment to be posted on the gist.
Examples:
  "This is a great Gist!"
  "Thanks for sharing this code snippet."

gist_id.description:
The unique identifier of the gist.
Examples:
  "29388372"
  "61e6f882424a427cb27205a22cd758e9"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_GITHUB_APP_FROM_A_MANIFEST
tools.title: Create a GitHub App from a manifest

annotations.title: Create a GitHub App from a manifest

tools.description: Use this action to finalize a GitHub App's creation by exchanging the temporary `code` (received as a URL parameter during the app manifest setup redirection) for the app's full configuration details.

code.description:
The temporary code provided by GitHub during the app manifest flow. This code is exchanged for the app's configuration.
Examples:
  "ghu_1A2b3C4d5E6f7G8h9I0j"
  "ghu_aSdFgHjKlQwErTyUiOp"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_GITHUB_PAGES_DEPLOYMENT
tools.title: Create a github pages deployment
tools.description: Creates a GitHub Pages deployment for a repository using a specified artifact and OIDC token, provided GitHub Pages is enabled and the artifact (containing static assets) is accessible.

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
Example: "Hello-World"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository (e.g., a GitHub username or organization name). This field is not case-sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

oidc_token.description: OIDC token from GitHub Actions for deployment authorization, typically from `secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN` with `id-token: write` permission.

artifact_id.description:
Identifier of a GitHub Actions artifact (e.g., .zip or .tar) with static assets for deployment. Artifact must belong to the repository. Either this or `artifact_url` is required.
Example: 123456789

environment.description:
Target environment for this GitHub Pages deployment. Defaults to `github-pages`.
Examples:
  "github-pages"
  "production"

artifact_url.description:
URL of a GitHub Actions artifact (e.g., .zip or .tar) with static assets for deployment. Artifact must belong to the repository. Either this or `artifact_id` is required.
Example: "https://pipelines.actions.githubusercontent.com/example/artifact_url"

pages_build_version.description:
Unique string identifying the build version for this deployment, typically the Git commit SHA. Defaults to `GITHUB_SHA`.
Examples:
  "GITHUB_SHA"
  "abc123def456ghi789"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_GITHUB_PAGES_SITE
tools.title: Create a github pages site
tools.description: Configures or updates GitHub Pages for a repository, setting build type and source; ensure a Pages workflow exists for 'workflow' `build_type`, or `source_branch` exists for 'legacy' or unspecified `build_type`. This action allows users to effectively manage their GitHub Pages site settings, specifying how the site is built and where the source files are located.

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the '.git' extension. This field is case-insensitive.
Examples:
  "Spoon-Knife"
  "my-docs-site"

owner.description:
The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is case-insensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github"

build_type.description:
Build process for the Pages site: 'legacy' (traditional GitHub Pages build) or 'workflow' (GitHub Actions). If omitted and `source_branch` is provided, defaults to 'legacy'. When 'workflow', `source_branch` and `source_path` are ignored.
Examples:
  "legacy"
  "workflow"

source__path.description:
Directory within `source_branch` for site source files (e.g., '/' for root, '/docs'). Ignored if `build_type` is 'workflow'.
Examples:
  "/"
  "/docs"

source__branch.description:
The branch for GitHub Pages source (e.g., 'main', 'gh-pages'). Required if `build_type` is 'legacy' or not specified. It is ignored if `build_type` is 'workflow'.
Examples:
  "main"
  "gh-pages"
  "docs"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_LABEL
tools.title: Create a label
tools.description: Creates a new label in a specified GitHub repository, provided the repository exists and the user has write permissions.

name.description:
The name of the label. Emoji can be added to label names, using either native emoji or colon-style markup. For example, typing `:strawberry:` will render the emoji ![:strawberry:](https://github.githubassets.com/images/icons/emoji/unicode/1f353.png ":strawberry:"). For a full list of available emoji and codes, see the "[Emoji cheat sheet](https://github.com/ikatyang/emoji-cheat-sheet)."
Examples:
  "bug"
  "enhancement"
  "documentation :memo:"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This is not case sensitive.
Example: "Spoon-Knife"

color.description:
The hexadecimal color code for the label (e.g., `f29513`), without the leading `#`. If not provided, GitHub will assign a random color.
Examples:
  "d73a4a"
  "0075ca"
  "cfd3d7"

owner.description:
The username of the account that owns the repository. This is not case sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

description.description:
A short description of the label. Maximum 100 characters.
Examples:
  "An issue with a bug."
  "A new feature or request."
  "Improvements or additions to documentation."

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_MILESTONE
tools.title: Create a milestone
tools.description: Creates a milestone in a GitHub repository for tracking progress on issues or pull requests; requires repository existence and user write permissions.

repo.description:
Repository name, without the `.git` extension (case-insensitive).
Examples:
  "hello-world"
  "my-repository-name"

owner.description:
Username of the repository owner (case-insensitive).
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github-username"

title.description:
Title for the new milestone.
Examples:
  "v1.0 Release"
  "Q3 Sprint Goals"

due_on.description:
Due date for the milestone (ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`).
Examples:
  "2024-12-31T23:59:59Z"
  "2025-03-15T18:30:00Z"

description.description:
Detailed description of the milestone.
Examples:
  "Tracking all issues and PRs for the upcoming v1.0 release."
  "Tasks for the third quarter sprint."

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_AN_AUTOLINK_REFERENCE_FOR_A_REPOSITORY
tools.title: Create an autolink reference for a repository

annotations.title: Create an autolink reference for a repository

tools.description: Creates a repository autolink to automatically convert text references (e.g., 'TICKET-123') into hyperlinks, using a unique `key_prefix` and a `url_template` that includes `<num>`.

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. The name is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "Spoon-Knife"
  "my-project"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. This can be a username or an organization name. The name is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "my-organization"

key_prefix.description:
Prefix that triggers the autolink (e.g., 'JIRA-'). When followed by an identifier, it's converted into a link. Must be non-empty and not contain spaces.
Examples:
  "JIRA-"
  "TICKET-"
  "DOC-"

url_template.description:
URL template for the autolink, using `<num>` as a placeholder for the reference identifier (e.g., 'https://example.atlassian.net/browse/<num>'). Behavior of `<num>` is determined by `is_alphanumeric`.
Examples:
  "https://example.atlassian.net/browse/<num>"
  "https://tracker.example.com/issues?id=<num>"

is_alphanumeric.description:
Specifies if the `<num>` placeholder in `url_template` matches alphanumeric characters (`A-Z` (case-insensitive), `0-9`, and `-`) or only numeric characters (`0-9`).
Examples:
  true
  false

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLE
tools.title: Create an environment variable
tools.description: Creates an encrypted environment variable for a pre-existing environment within a GitHub repository; will fail if the variable name already exists.

name.description:
The name of the environment variable to create (e.g., `API_KEY`).
Examples:
  "CI_TOKEN"
  "DATABASE_URL"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
Example: "hello-world"

owner.description:
The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

value.description:
The value of the environment variable (e.g., `your_secret_token`). This value will be encrypted.
Examples:
  "s3cr3t_v4lu3"
  "postgres://user:secret@localhost:5432/mydb"

environment_name.description:
The name of the environment for which to create the variable. The name must be URL encoded if it contains special characters (e.g., slashes `/` must be replaced with `%2F`).
Examples:
  "production"
  "staging%2Ffeature-branch"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ISSUE
tools.title: Create an issue
tools.description: Creates a new issue in a GitHub repository, requiring the repository to exist and have issues enabled; specific fields like assignees, milestone, or labels may require push access.

body.description:
The detailed textual contents of the new issue.
Examples:
  "Detailed description of the bug with steps to reproduce."
  "I think adding a dark mode would improve user experience..."

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension (case-insensitive).
Examples:
  "Spoon-Knife"
  "linux"

owner.description:
The GitHub account owner of the repository (case-insensitive).
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "torvalds"

title.description:
The title for the new issue.
Examples:
  "Found a critical bug"
  "Feature request: Add dark mode"

labels.description:
Array of label names to associate with this issue (generally case-insensitive). NOTE: Only users with push access can set labels; they are silently dropped otherwise. Pass an empty list to clear all labels.
Examples:
  ["bug","critical"]
  ["enhancement","ui"]
  ["documentation"]

assignee.description:
Login for the user to whom this issue should be assigned. NOTE: Only users with push access can set the assignee; it is silently dropped otherwise. **This field is deprecated in favor of `assignees`.**
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "monalisa"

assignees.description:
GitHub login names for users to assign to this issue. NOTE: Only users with push access can set assignees; they are silently dropped otherwise.
Examples:
  ["octocat"]
  ["monalisa","hubot"]

milestone.description:
The ID of the milestone to associate this issue with (e.g., "5"). NOTE: Only users with push access can set the milestone; it is silently dropped otherwise.
Examples:
  "1"
  "5"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ISSUE_COMMENT
tools.title: Create an issue comment
tools.description: Creates a new comment on an existing GitHub issue or pull request within the specified repository.

body.description:
Comment content in GitHub Flavored Markdown.
Examples:
  "This is a **bold** comment!"
  "Thanks for the update :+1:"
  "Fixes #123"

repo.description:
Name of the repository (without `.git` extension); not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "Spoon-Knife"
  "my-awesome-project"

owner.description:
Account owner of the repository (username or organization); not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "my-organization"

issue_number.description:
Number identifying the issue or pull request for the comment.
Examples:
  42
  101

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ORGANIZATION_PROJECT
tools.title: Create an organization project
tools.description: Creates a new classic project board within a specified GitHub organization.

org.description:
Name of the organization (not case-sensitive).
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github"

body.description:
Body or description for the new project.
Examples:
  "Tasks and milestones for the Q1 roadmap."
  "Detailed plan and discussion for the website redesign project."

name.description:
Name for the new project.
Examples:
  "Q1 Roadmap"
  "Website Redesign"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ORGANIZATION_REPOSITORY
tools.title: Create an organization repository
tools.description: Creates a new repository within a specified GitHub organization, with options for detailed configuration including visibility, features, merge strategies, initial commit, and templates.

org.description:
Name of the organization where the repository will be created (case-insensitive).
Example: "MyGitHubOrg"

name.description:
Name of the new repository.
Example: "new-awesome-project"

private.description: Whether the repository is private. `visibility` takes precedence if both are set.

team_id.description:
ID of the team to grant access to this repository within the organization.
Example: 12345

homepage.description:
URL for the repository's homepage.
Example: "https://example.com/my-awesome-project"

auto_init.description: Create an initial commit with an empty README.

visibility.description:
Repository visibility: 'public' (visible to everyone) or 'private' (visible to collaborators).
Example: "public"

description.description:
Short description of the repository.
Example: "A project to demonstrate awesome capabilities."

is_template.description: Make this repository a template repository.

has_projects.description: Enable projects for this repository. Fails if organization has disabled repository projects and this is true.

license_template.description:
License template keyword (e.g., "mit", "apache-2.0"). See [GitHub license documentation](https://docs.github.com/articles/licensing-a-repository/#searching-github-by-license-type) for options.
Example: "mit"

custom_properties.description:
JSON string containing custom properties for the repository as a key-value object. Example: '{"project_lead": "octocat", "status": "alpha"}'
Example: "{\"project_lead\": \"octocat\", \"status\": \"alpha\"}"

allow_merge_commit.description: Allow merging pull requests with a merge commit.

gitignore_template.description:
Name of the .gitignore template to apply (e.g., "Python", "Node"). Refer to the [GitHub gitignore template list](https://github.com/github/gitignore).
Example: "Python"

merge_commit_title.description:
Default title for merge commits: 'PR_TITLE' or 'MERGE_MESSAGE'.
Example: "MERGE_MESSAGE"

merge_commit_message.description:
Default message for merge commits: 'PR_TITLE', 'PR_BODY', or 'BLANK'.
Example: "PR_BODY"

delete_branch_on_merge.description: Automatically delete head branches when pull requests are merged. Requires organization owner privileges if true.

squash_merge_commit_title.description:
Default title for squash merge commits: 'PR_TITLE' or 'COMMIT_OR_PR_TITLE'.
Example: "PR_TITLE"

squash_merge_commit_message.description:
Default message for squash merge commits: 'PR_BODY', 'COMMIT_MESSAGES', or 'BLANK'.
Example: "PR_BODY"

use_squash_pr_title_as_default.description: DEPRECATED: Use `squash_merge_commit_title`. Default to pull request title for squash-merge commits.

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ORGANIZATION_VARIABLE
tools.title: Create an organization variable
tools.description: Creates a new, uniquely named GitHub Actions variable for an organization, with configurable repository access visibility (all, private, or selected).

org.description:
The name of the GitHub organization. This name is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "github"
  "my-organization"

name.description:
The name of the organization variable. Must be unique at the organization level.
Examples:
  "CI_TOKEN"
  "DEPLOY_SERVER_URL"

value.description:
The value of the organization variable.
Examples:
  "your_secret_token_value"
  "https://api.staging.example.com"

visibility.description:
Controls which repositories in the organization can access the variable. Accepted values are 'all' (all repositories), 'private' (only private repositories), or 'selected' (specific repositories designated by `selected_repository_ids`).
Examples:
  "all"
  "private"
  "selected"

selected_repository_ids.description:
A list of repository integer IDs that can access this organization variable. This field is required and only applicable when `visibility` is set to 'selected'.
Examples:
  "[1296269, 1296270]"
  "[98765]"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ORGANIZATION_WEBHOOK
tools.title: Create an organization webhook
tools.description: Creates a webhook for a GitHub organization to deliver event notifications to a configured URL.

org.description:
The name of the GitHub organization. This name is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "my-cool-org"
  "GitHub"

name.description: The name of the webhook. Must be "web" for organization webhooks.

active.description: Boolean indicating if the webhook is active. `true` sends notifications, `false` does not. Defaults to `true`.

events.description:
List of event names to trigger the webhook. Use `['*']` for all events. Defaults to `['push']` if not specified. See GitHub docs for event types.
Examples:
  ["push","issues"]
  ["*"]
  ["release"]
  ["check_run"]

config__url.description:
The target URL for webhook payload delivery. This URL is a mandatory part of the webhook's `config` object and will receive POST requests for subscribed events.
Examples:
  "https://example.com/webhook"
  "https://my-service.com/github-events"

config__secret.description:
Optional secret for generating an HMAC hex digest for payload verification (X-Hub-Signature-256 header). If provided, this is used as the key.
Examples:
  "s3cr3tT0k3n"
  "mySup3rS3cur3K3y"

config__password.description:
Password for basic authentication if the webhook endpoint (`config_url`) requires it, corresponding to `config_username`.
Examples:
  "p@$$wOrd"
  "securePassword123"

config__username.description:
Username for basic authentication if the webhook endpoint (`config_url`) requires it. Use only if your endpoint is protected by basic auth.
Examples:
  "webhook-user"
  "admin"

config__content__type.description:
The media type for serializing webhook payloads. Supported: `json`, `form`. GitHub API defaults to `form` if this field is not set or is `None`.
Examples:
  "json"
  "form"

config__insecure__ssl.description:
Controls SSL certificate verification for `config_url`. '1' disables verification (not recommended), '0' enables. GitHub API defaults to '0' (verification enabled) if this field is not set or is `None`.
Examples:
  "0"
  "1"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_PROJECT_CARD
tools.title: Create a project card
tools.description: Creates a project card in a GitHub project column; the request body must contain either a `note` for a note-only card, or both `content_id` (ID of an issue or pull request) and `content_type` (e.g., 'Issue', 'PullRequest'). This action facilitates the organization of tasks and issues in a project management context within GitHub.

column_id.description:
The unique identifier of the project column where the card will be created. This value is used as a path parameter in the API request URL (e.g., `/projects/columns/{column_id}/cards`).
Example: "1234567"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_PROJECT_COLUMN
tools.title: Create a project column
tools.description: Creates a new column in a GitHub project (classic).

name.description:
The name for the new project column.
Examples:
  "To Do"
  "In Progress"
  "Done"

project_id.description: The unique identifier of the target GitHub project (classic) where the new column will be created.

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_PULL_REQUEST
tools.title: Create a pull request
tools.description: Creates a pull request in a GitHub repository, requiring existing `base` and `head` branches; `title` or `issue` must be provided.

base.description:
The name of the branch you want the changes pulled into. This must be an existing branch on the current (target) repository. You cannot submit a pull request to one repository that requests a merge to a base branch of another repository. 
Examples:
  "main"
  "develop"

body.description:
The detailed description or contents of the pull request.
Examples:
  "This PR introduces a new feature that does X, Y, and Z."
  "Fixes #42 by addressing the off-by-one error."

head.description:
The name of the branch where your changes are implemented. For cross-repository pull requests, namespace `head` with the source owner and branch, like `username:branch`.
Examples:
  "feature-branch"
  "octocat:my-feature-branch"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.
Example: "Spoon-Knife"

draft.description:
Indicates whether the pull request should be created as a draft. Draft pull requests cannot be merged until marked as ready for review.
Examples:
  true
  false

issue.description:
The number of an existing issue in the repository to convert into a pull request. If provided, the issue's title and body may be used for the pull request. Required if `title` is not specified.
Examples:
  "123"
  "456"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. This name is not case-sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

title.description:
The title of the new pull request. Required unless `issue` is specified.
Examples:
  "Amazing new feature"
  "Fix for critical bug #123"

head_repo.description:
The name of the repository (e.g., 'octocat/Hello-World') where the changes in the pull request were made. This field is required for cross-repository pull requests if both the source and target repositories are owned by the same organization but are different repositories.
Example: "octocat/my-forked-repo"

maintainer_can_modify.description:
Indicates whether maintainers of the upstream repository can modify the pull request. This is primarily relevant for pull requests originating from forks.
Examples:
  true
  false

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REFERENCE
tools.title: Create a reference
tools.description: Creates a Git reference (e.g., a branch or tag) in a repository; the repository must not be empty prior to this operation.

ref.description:
Fully qualified reference to create (e.g., `refs/heads/master`, `refs/tags/v1.0.0`). Must start with `refs/` and contain at least two slashes.
Examples:
  "refs/heads/new-feature-branch"
  "refs/tags/v1.2.3"

sha.description:
SHA-1 hash of an existing commit in the repository that the new reference will point to.
Examples:
  "aa218f56b14c9653891f9e74264a383fa43fefbd"
  "1234567890abcdef1234567890abcdef12345678"

repo.description:
The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.
Example: "Hello-World"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REGISTRATION_TOKEN_FOR_AN_ORGANIZATION
tools.title: Create a registration token for an organization

annotations.title: Create a registration token for an organization

tools.description: Generates a temporary (one-hour) registration token to add a new self-hosted runner to an organization for GitHub Actions.

org.description:
The name of the organization. This name is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octo-org"
  "github"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REGISTRATION_TOKEN_FOR_A_REPOSITORY
tools.title: Create a registration token for a repository

annotations.title: Create a registration token for a repository

tools.description: Generates a time-limited token required to register a new self-hosted runner with a specific repository.

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "hello-world"
  "linguist"

owner.description:
The username of the account or the organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_RELEASE
tools.title: Create a release
tools.description: Creates a release in a GitHub repository for a specified tag; the tag must be unique for published releases, and if a `discussion_category_name` is given, it must already exist.

body.description:
A detailed description of the release. Markdown formatting is supported.
Examples:
  "This release includes new features X, Y, and bug fixes for Z."
  "# New Features\n- Feature A\n- Feature B"

name.description:
The title of the release. If omitted and `generate_release_notes` is false, it defaults to the `tag_name`.
Examples:
  "Version 1.0.0"
  "My Awesome Release"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the .git extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "Spoon-Knife"
  "our-awesome-project"

draft.description: Set to `true` to create an unpublished (draft) release. Defaults to `false`.

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository (username or organization name). This field is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "my-company"

tag_name.description:
The name of the tag for this release. This tag must be unique for published releases.
Examples:
  "v1.0.0"
  "v1.0.1-alpha"

prerelease.description: Set to `true` to identify this release as a pre-release. Defaults to `false`.

make_latest.description:
Specifies if this release should be marked as the latest for the repository. Valid values: 'true', 'false', 'legacy'. Defaults to 'true'. Draft releases and prereleases cannot be set as 'latest'.
Examples:
  "true"
  "false"
  "legacy"

target_commitish.description:
Specifies the commitish value (e.g., branch name, tag name, or commit SHA) from which the Git tag is created. Defaults to the repository's default branch if the tag specified in `tag_name` doesn't exist yet.
Examples:
  "main"
  "develop"
  "c1f67a4f091588259dd3f8a27378e170d40c8472"

generate_release_notes.description: Set to `true` to automatically generate the release title (`name`) and description (`body`) from the commit history since the last release. Defaults to `false`.

discussion_category_name.description:
If specified, a new discussion will be created in this category and linked to the release. The category must already exist in the repository's discussions.
Examples:
  "Announcements"
  "General"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REMOVE_TOKEN_FOR_AN_ORGANIZATION
tools.title: Create a remove token for an organization

annotations.title: Create a remove token for an organization

tools.description: Generates a token, valid for one hour, to authenticate removing a self-hosted runner from an organization.

org.description:
The unique identifier or name of the GitHub organization. This name is not case-sensitive. For example, if your organization's URL is github.com/my-org, 'my-org' is the value.
Example: "my-github-org"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REMOVE_TOKEN_FOR_A_REPOSITORY
tools.title: Create a remove token for a repository

annotations.title: Create a remove token for a repository

tools.description: Generates a temporary (one-hour validity) token required to unregister and remove a self-hosted runner from a repository.

repo.description:
Name of the repository, without the `.git` extension (not case-sensitive).
Example: "hello-world"

owner.description:
Username of the account owning the repository (not case-sensitive).
Example: "octo-org"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REPLY_FOR_A_REVIEW_COMMENT
tools.title: Create a reply for a review comment

annotations.title: Create a reply for a review comment

tools.description: Posts a reply to a specific review comment on a GitHub pull request, requiring the repository, pull request, and original comment to exist, and a non-empty reply body.

body.description:
The text of the reply to the review comment.
Example: "Thanks for the clarification!"

repo.description:
The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.
Example: "Hello-World"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

comment_id.description:
The unique identifier of the comment to which the reply is being made.
Example: "10233"

pull_number.description:
The number that identifies the pull request.
Example: "1347"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REPOSITORY_DISPATCH_EVENT
tools.title: Create a repository dispatch event
tools.description: Triggers a GitHub Actions workflow or a webhook on a repository by creating a repository dispatch event, allowing programmatic triggering of workflows based on events outside of GitHub.

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension (not case-sensitive).
Examples:
  "hello-world"
  "my-awesome-project"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository (not case-sensitive).
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "my-organization"

event_type.description:
Custom webhook event name (100 characters or fewer).
Examples:
  "deploy_staging"
  "run_integration_tests"
  "custom_event_1"

client_payload.description:
JSON string containing extra information for the webhook event (max 10 top-level properties), passed to the triggered workflow or action. Example: '{"ref": "main", "sha": "abc123"}'
Examples:
  "{\"ref\": \"main\", \"sha\": \"0123456789abcdef\", \"actor\": \"monalisa\"}"
  "{\"custom_data\": \"value1\", \"user_id\": 123, \"trigger_reason\": \"manual_dispatch\"}"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REPOSITORY_FOR_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER
tools.title: Create a repository for the authenticated user

annotations.title: Create a repository for the authenticated user

tools.description: Creates a new repository for the authenticated user, optionally within an organization if `team_id` is specified.

name.description:
The name of the repository. Must be unique within your account. Will be used in the repository URL (github.com/username/repo-name). Can only contain alphanumeric characters, hyphens, underscores, and periods.
Examples:
  "my-new-repo"
  "hello-world"

private.description: Whether the repository is private (true) or public (false).

team_id.description:
The ID of the team to be granted access. Only valid if creating in an organization.
Example: 12345

homepage.description:
A URL with more information about the repository.
Example: "https://example.com/my-new-repo"

auto_init.description: Whether to initialize the repository with a README.

description.description:
A short description of the repository.
Examples:
  "This is a project about X."
  "My personal blog."

is_template.description: Whether this repository is a template repository.

has_downloads.description: Whether downloads are enabled (deprecated by GitHub and may not be configurable).

allow_auto_merge.description: Whether to allow auto-merge on pull requests.

allow_merge_commit.description: Whether to allow merging pull requests with a merge commit.

allow_rebase_merge.description: Whether to allow rebase-merging pull requests.

allow_squash_merge.description: Whether to allow squash-merging pull requests.

merge_commit_title.description:
The default title for a merge commit. `PR_TITLE` uses the pull request's title. `MERGE_MESSAGE` uses a classic title like 'Merge pull request #123 from branch-name'.
Examples:
  "PR_TITLE"
  "MERGE_MESSAGE"

merge_commit_message.description:
The default message for a merge commit. `PR_BODY` uses the pull request's body. `PR_TITLE` uses the pull request's title. `BLANK` results in a blank commit message.
Examples:
  "PR_BODY"
  "PR_TITLE"
  "BLANK"

delete_branch_on_merge.description: Whether to automatically delete head branches when pull requests are merged.

squash_merge_commit_title.description:
The default title for a squash merge commit. `PR_TITLE` uses the pull request's title. `COMMIT_OR_PR_TITLE` uses the commit's title (if only one commit) or the pull request's title (if multiple commits).
Examples:
  "PR_TITLE"
  "COMMIT_OR_PR_TITLE"

squash_merge_commit_message.description:
The default message for a squash merge commit. `PR_BODY` uses the pull request's body. `COMMIT_MESSAGES` uses the branch's commit messages. `BLANK` results in a blank commit message.
Examples:
  "PR_BODY"
  "COMMIT_MESSAGES"
  "BLANK"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REPOSITORY_FROM_AN_UNPUBLISHED_CODESPACE
tools.title: Create a repository from an unpublished codespace

annotations.title: Create a repository from an unpublished codespace

tools.description: Publishes the specified codespace to a new repository, using the codespace's current state as the initial commit.

name.description:
The desired name for the new repository to be created from the codespace. If omitted, GitHub might generate a name (e.g., based on the codespace name).
Examples:
  "my-new-project"
  "codespace-to-repo-conversion"

private.description: Specifies the visibility of the new repository. Set to `true` for a private repository, or `false` for a public one. Defaults to `false` (public).

codespace_name.description:
The unique name of the codespace to be published as a new repository. This codespace must exist, be unpublished, and belong to the authenticated user.
Example: "monalisa-glorious-space-machine-vrg5779x7p92r7w"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REPOSITORY_PROJECT
tools.title: Create a repository project
tools.description: Creates a new classic project board within a specified repository; classic projects must be enabled for the target repository.

body.description:
An optional detailed description for the project board.
Examples:
  "Tasks and milestones for the upcoming website redesign."
  "Product features and initiatives for the fourth quarter."

name.description:
The name of the project board to be created.
Examples:
  "New Website Launch Plan"
  "Q4 Roadmap"

repo.description: The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REPOSITORY_RULESET
tools.title: Create a repository ruleset
tools.description: Creates a uniquely named ruleset for a repository, defining rules for branches or tags with specified enforcement, conditions, and bypass actors.

name.description:
Unique name for the ruleset.
Example: "My branch protection ruleset"

repo.description:
Name of the repository, without the `.git` extension (not case-sensitive).
Example: "Hello-World"

owner.description:
Account owner of the repository (not case-sensitive).
Example: "octocat"

rules.description:
Array of rule objects as a JSON string to be enforced. Each must have `type` and may have `parameters`. Refer to GitHub API docs for available rule types and parameters. Example: '[{"type": "creation"}, {"type": "deletion"}]'
Example: "[{\"type\": \"creation\"}, {\"type\": \"deletion\"}, {\"type\": \"required_linear_history\"}]"

target.description:
The target of the ruleset, whether it applies to branches or tags.
Examples:
  "branch"
  "tag"

enforcement.description:
Enforcement level: `disabled` (ruleset is not enforced), `active` (ruleset is enforced), or `evaluate` (test rules before enforcing; GitHub Enterprise only).
Examples:
  "disabled"
  "active"
  "evaluate"

bypass_actors.description:
Actors that can bypass rules in this ruleset as a JSON string. Each actor object requires `actor_id`, `actor_type` (e.g., 'Team', 'Integration'), and `bypass_mode` (e.g., 'always'). Example: '[{"actor_id": 1, "actor_type": "Team", "bypass_mode": "always"}]'
Example: "[{\"actor_id\": 1, \"actor_type\": \"Team\", \"bypass_mode\": \"always\"}, {\"actor_id\": 5, \"actor_type\": \"RepositoryRole\", \"bypass_mode\": \"pull_request\"}]"

conditions__ref__name__exclude.description:
Ref names or patterns to exclude. Condition fails if any pattern matches the ref name.
Example: ["refs/heads/release/*","refs/heads/experimental-*"]

conditions__ref__name__include.description:
Ref names/patterns to include. Condition passes if one pattern matches the ref name. Use `~DEFAULT_BRANCH` for default branch, `~ALL` for all branches.
Example: ["refs/heads/main","~DEFAULT_BRANCH","refs/heads/feature-*"]

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REPOSITORY_USING_A_TEMPLATE
tools.title: Create a repository using a template

annotations.title: Create a repository using a template

tools.description: Creates a new repository from an existing template repository; the authenticated user must have access to the template and, if creating in an organization, repository creation permissions within it.

name.description:
The desired name for the new repository to be created.
Example: "my-new-service"

owner.description:
The username or organization name that will own the new repository. Defaults to the authenticated user if not provided.
Examples:
  "my-github-username"
  "my-cool-org"

private.description:
Set to `true` to create a private repository, or `false` to create a public repository.
Examples:
  true
  false

description.description:
A brief summary or description for the new repository.
Example: "A new microservice for processing widgets."

template_repo.description:
The name of the template repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
Example: "template-for-projects"

template_owner.description:
The username or organization name that owns the template repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
Example: "octo-org"

include_all_branches.description:
Set to `true` to copy the directory structure and files from all branches of the template repository, not just the default branch.
Examples:
  true
  false

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REPOSITORY_VARIABLE
tools.title: Create a repository variable
tools.description: Creates a new, unencrypted variable in a repository for GitHub Actions workflows; fails if a variable with the same name already exists.

name.description:
The name of the variable to create. Variable names are case-sensitive and can only contain alphanumeric characters ([a-z], [A-Z], [0-9]) or underscores (_). They cannot start with the `GITHUB_` prefix, and spaces are not allowed.
Examples:
  "DEPLOY_SERVER_URL"
  "BUILD_VERSION"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case sensitive.
Examples:
  "hello-world"
  "my-app-repository"

owner.description:
The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "my-organization"

value.description:
The value of the variable. This will be stored as a string.
Examples:
  "https://prod.example.com"
  "1.2.3"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REPOSITORY_WEBHOOK
tools.title: Create a repository webhook
tools.description: Creates a webhook for a specified repository; requires admin permissions on the repository.

name.description:
Name of the webhook. Use `web`. This parameter currently only accepts `web` and defaults to `web` if not provided.
Example: "web"

repo.description:
The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. This name is not case sensitive.
Example: "Hello-World"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. This name is not case sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

active.description:
Determines if notifications are sent when the webhook is triggered. `true` sends notifications (active), `false` disables them (inactive).
Examples:
  true
  false

events.description:
List of events to trigger the webhook (e.g., `['push']`, `['issues']`). See GitHub documentation for 'webhook event payloads'.
Examples:
  ["push"]
  ["issues","pull_request"]
  ["*"]

config__url.description:
The URL to which webhook payloads will be delivered via POST for subscribed events.
Example: "https://example.com/webhook"

config__secret.description:
Optional secret string for HMAC hex digest in delivery signature headers, enhancing security. See GitHub's 'delivery signature headers' documentation for details.
Example: "mysecrettoken"

config__content__type.description:
Media type for serializing payloads: `json` or `form`. Defaults to `form` if not specified. `json` delivers JSON, `form` delivers URL-encoded data.
Examples:
  "json"
  "form"

config__insecure__ssl.description:
Determines SSL certificate verification for the payload URL: "0" to verify SSL (recommended), or "1" to skip. Defaults to "0" (verify SSL) if not provided.
Examples:
  "0"
  "1"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REVIEW_COMMENT_FOR_A_PULL_REQUEST
tools.title: Create a review comment for a pull request

annotations.title: Create a review comment for a pull request

tools.description: Creates a review comment on a pull request's diff, targeting a specific line, range of lines, an entire file, or replying to an existing comment.

body.description:
Text content of the review comment.
Examples:
  "This looks great!"
  "Could you clarify this section?"

line.description:
**Required unless `subject_type` is 'file'**. Line number in the diff for the comment; for multi-line, this is the last line of the range.
Example: "25"

path.description:
Relative path of the file for the comment.
Examples:
  "file1.txt"
  "src/main.py"

repo.description:
Repository name without the `.git` extension (not case sensitive).
Example: "Spoon-Knife"

side.description: Side of the diff (`LEFT` or `RIGHT`) for the comment in a split diff view; for multi-line comments, refers to the last line of the range.

owner.description:
Account owner of the repository (not case sensitive).
Example: "octocat"

position.description: **Deprecated: Use `line` instead.** Position in the diff hunk for the comment (not the file line number).

commit_id.description:
SHA of the commit for the comment. Using an outdated `commit_id` can misplace the comment if lines change.
Example: "c5b97d5ae6c19d5c5df71a34c7fbeeda2479ccbc"

start_line.description:
**Required for multi-line comments unless `in_reply_to` is used.** First line in the diff for a multi-line comment.
Example: "20"

start_side.description: **Required for multi-line comments unless `in_reply_to` is used.** Starting side of the diff (`LEFT` or `RIGHT`) for a multi-line comment.

in_reply_to.description:
ID of an existing review comment to reply to. If provided, other location parameters (except `body`) are ignored.
Example: "8663694"

pull_number.description:
Identifier of the pull request.
Example: "1347"

subject_type.description: Level of the comment target: `line` (specific line) or `file` (entire file). Defaults to `line` if not provided.

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REVIEW_FOR_A_PULL_REQUEST
tools.title: Create a review for a pull request

annotations.title: Create a review for a pull request

tools.description: Creates a pull request review, allowing approval, change requests, or comments; `body` is required if `event` is `REQUEST_CHANGES` or `COMMENT`, and omitting `event` makes the review `PENDING`.

body.description:
Review's main body text; required if `event` is `REQUEST_CHANGES` or `COMMENT`.
Examples:
  "This looks great overall!"
  "Please address the comments below."

repo.description:
Repository name, without the `.git` extension (case-insensitive).
Examples:
  "Hello-World"
  "my-private-repo"

event.description:
Review action type (`APPROVE`, `REQUEST_CHANGES`, `COMMENT`); if omitted, review is `PENDING` and requires later submission.
Examples:
  "APPROVE"
  "REQUEST_CHANGES"
  "COMMENT"

owner.description:
Username of the account owning the repository (case-insensitive).
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "my-organization"

line.description: The line number in the diff to comment on (required for single-line comments)

path.description: The relative path to the file being commented on

side.description: The side of the diff to place the comment on (LEFT or RIGHT)

start_line.description: The start line number for multi-line comments

start_side.description: The side of the diff to start a multi-line comment on

comments.description:
Inline draft review comments. Each object requires `path` (relative file path) and `body` (comment text). Optionally, specify `line` (or `start_line` for multi-line), and `side` (or `start_side`) for diff location. `position` is deprecated; use `line`. Example: `[{'path': 'file.py', 'line': 10, 'body': 'Refactor this.'}]`
Examples:
  "[{\"path\": \"README.md\", \"line\": 5, \"body\": \"Needs more detail here.\"}]"
  "[{\"path\": \"src/main.py\", \"start_line\": 10, \"line\": 12, \"side\": \"RIGHT\", \"body\": \"This logic can be simplified.\"}]"

commit_id.description:
SHA of the commit to review; defaults to the latest pull request commit. Outdated SHAs may lead to stale comments.
Example: "c4d3a6f8a0c2b0e8e2b8f3c9e8b4b0e5b0b0e0e0"

pull_number.description:
Identifying number of the pull request.
Examples:
  1
  123

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_SCOPED_ACCESS_TOKEN
tools.title: Create a scoped access token
tools.description: Exchanges a user-to-server token for a new, fine-grained scoped access token for a GitHub App, requiring `client_id`, `access_token`, either `target` or `target_id`, and at least one permission; for repository-specific scoping, provide either `repositories` (names) or `repository_ids` (IDs), but not both.

target.description:
Username or organization name for scoping the new token. Required if `target_id` is not provided.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github-org"

client_id.description:
Client ID of the GitHub App.
Example: "iv1.1234567890abcdef"

target_id.description:
ID of the user or organization for scoping the new token. Required if `target` is not provided.
Examples:
  "12345"
  "67890"

access_token.description:
User-to-server access token to be exchanged for a new scoped token.
Example: "ghu_xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx"

repositories.description:
Repository names to scope the new token to. Cannot be used if `repository_ids` is specified.
Example: ["my-repo","another-repo"]

repository_ids.description:
Repository IDs to scope the new token to. Cannot be used if `repositories` is specified.
Example: ["1234567","7654321"]

permissions__pages.description:
Permission for GitHub Pages settings, statuses, configurations, builds, and creating new builds. Applies to target repositories.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__checks.description:
Permission for checks on code (e.g., CI statuses). Applies to target repositories.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__issues.description:
Permission for issues, comments, assignees, labels, and milestones. Applies to target repositories.

  "read"
  "write"

permissions__actions.description:
Permission for GitHub Actions workflows, workflow runs, and artifacts. Applies to target repositories.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__members.description:
Permission for organization members and teams. Applies to target organization.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__profile.description:
Permission to manage profile settings for the user account. Applies to target user.
Example: "write"

permissions__secrets.description:
Permission for repository secrets (e.g., Actions secrets). Applies to target repositories.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__contents.description:
Permission for repository contents, commits, branches, downloads, releases, and merges. Applies to target repositories.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__metadata.description:
Read-only permission for repository metadata, search, and collaborator listing. Applies to target repositories.
Example: "read"

permissions__packages.description:
Permission for packages in GitHub Packages. Applies to target repositories or organization.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__starring.description:
Permission to list and manage repositories a user is starring. Applies to target user.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__statuses.description:
Permission for commit statuses. Applies to target repositories.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__followers.description:
Permission to manage followers for the user account. Applies to target user.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__gpg__keys.description:
Permission to view and manage GPG keys for the user account. Applies to target user.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__workflows.description:
Permission for updating GitHub Actions workflow files. Requires `contents: write`. Applies to target repositories.
Example: "write"

permissions__codespaces.description:
Permission for Codespaces. Applies to target user/organization if repositories are not specified, otherwise to target repositories.

  "read"
  "write"

permissions__deployments.description:
Permission for deployments and deployment statuses. Applies to target repositories.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__environments.description:
Permission for repository environments. Applies to target repositories.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__single__file.description:
Permission to manage a single file. Requires `repository_ids` set to a single repository and `repositories` to a single file path.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__administration.description:
Permission for repository administration (settings, teams, collaborators). Applies to target repositories.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__git__ssh__keys.description:
Permission to manage Git SSH keys for the user account. Applies to target user.

  "read"
  "write"

permissions__pull__requests.description:
Permission for pull requests, comments, assignees, labels, milestones, and merges. Applies to target repositories.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__email__addresses.description:
Permission to manage email addresses for the user account. Applies to target user.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__security__events.description:
Permission for security events (e.g., code scanning alerts). Applies to target repositories.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__repository__hooks.description:
Permission for repository webhooks. Applies to target repositories.
Examples:
  "read"
  "write"

permissions__team__discussions.description:
Permission for team discussions and related comments. Applies to target organization.
Examples:
  "read"

permissions__organization__plan.description:
Read-only permission for viewing an organization's billing plan. Applies to target organization.

permissions__dependabot__secrets.description:
Permission for Dependabot secrets for targeted repositories.
Examples:

permissions__interaction__limits.description:
Permission to view and manage interaction limits on a repository. Applies to target repositories or organization.

permissions__organization__hooks.description:
Permission for organization webhooks. Applies to target organization.

  "read"

permissions__organization__events.description:
Read-only permission to view organization audit log events. Applies to target organization.

permissions__repository__projects.description:
Permission for repository projects, columns, and cards. Applies to target repositories.

permissions__organization__secrets.description:
Permission for organization-level secrets (e.g., Actions secrets). Applies to target organization.

Permission for Dependabot alerts. Applies to target repositories.

permissions__organization__packages.description:
Permission for organization-level GitHub Packages. Applies to target organization.

permissions__organization__projects.description:
Permission for organization projects and projects beta (if available). Applies to target organization.

permissions__secret__scanning__alerts.description:
Permission for secret scanning alerts. Applies to target repositories.

permissions__organization__custom__roles.description:
Permission for custom repository roles within an organization. Applies to target organization.

permissions__organization__administratio.description:
Permission for administrative settings of an organization. Applies to target organization.
