tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_SNAPSHOT_OF_DEPENDENCIES_FOR_A_REPOSITORY
tools.title: Create a dependency snapshot
tools.description: Creates a snapshot of a repository's dependencies to populate the GitHub dependency graph and enable security alerts; `sha` must be a 40-character commit ID, `ref` a fully qualified Git reference (e.g., `refs/heads/main`), and `scanned` an ISO 8601 timestamp.

ref.description:
Git reference (fully qualified, e.g., `refs/heads/main`) of the repository branch/tag that triggered this snapshot.
Examples:
  "refs/heads/main"
  "refs/tags/v1.0"

sha.description:
Commit SHA (maximum 40 characters) associated with this dependency snapshot.
Example: "ddc90423135c402f345907a6032d9054137dd9ee"

repo.description:
Repository name, without `.git` extension (name is not case-sensitive).
Example: "hello-world"

owner.description:
Account owner of the repository (name is not case-sensitive).
Example: "octocat"

job__id.description: Optional external ID of the job that generated this snapshot.

scanned.description:
UTC timestamp (ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ) when the snapshot was taken.
Example: "2023-10-26T14:30:00Z"

version.description: Version of the dependency snapshot submission, typically of the manifest or lock file format.

metadata.description: Optional user-defined metadata as a JSON string for domain-specific information. Limited to 8 keys with scalar values (e.g., string, number, boolean). Example: '{"key1": "value1", "key2": 123}'

manifests.description: Optional collection of package manifests as a JSON string (e.g., package-lock.json, pom.xml). Keys are manifest file names; values detail dependencies. Example: '{"package-lock.json": {"name": "...", "resolved": {...}}}'

detector__url.description:
Optional URL of the detector tool used.
Example: "https://jeremylong.github.io/DependencyCheck/"

detector__name.description:
Optional name of the tool used to detect dependencies.
Example: "dependency-check"

job__html__url.description:
Optional URL for the job that generated this snapshot.
Example: "https://github.com/octocat/hello-world/actions/runs/123"

job__correlator.description:
Optional string to group snapshots. For a given `job.correlator` and `detector.name`, only the 'latest' snapshot is current. Useful to distinguish detection runs (e.g., concatenating GITHUB_WORKFLOW and GITHUB_JOB).
Example: "my-workflow-job-123"

detector__version.description:
Optional version of the detector tool used.
Example: "7.0.0"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_TAG_OBJECT
tools.title: Create a tag object
tools.description: Creates an annotated Git tag object in a repository, pointing to an existing Git object (commit, tree, or blob) defined by its SHA and ensuring the `type` field correctly specifies the object's type.

tag.description:
The name of the tag, typically a version identifier (e.g., "v0.0.1").
Example: "v1.0.0"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.
Example: "Hello-World"

type.description:
The type of the Git object being tagged.
Example: "commit"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. This name is not case-sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

object.description:
The SHA of the Git object (commit, tree, or blob) that this tag is pointing to.
Example: "c3d0be41ecbe669545ee3e94d31ed9a4bc91ee3c"

message.description:
The message associated with the tag.
Example: "Initial release v1.0.0"

tagger__date.description:
The timestamp for when this object was tagged. This should be in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.
Example: "2014-11-07T22:01:45Z"

tagger__name.description:
The name of the person creating the tag.
Example: "Monalisa Octocat"

tagger__email.description:
The email address of the person creating the tag.
Example: "monalisa.octocat@example.com"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_TAG_PROTECTION_STATE_FOR_A_REPOSITORY
tools.title: Create a tag protection state for a repository

annotations.title: Create a tag protection state for a repository

tools.description: Creates a tag protection rule for a repository using a glob pattern; note: tag protections are deprecated (sunset August 30, 2024), migrate to repository rulesets.

repo.description:
The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. Not case sensitive.
Examples:
  "Hello-World"
  "my-awesome-project"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository (username or organization name). Not case sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "my-organization"

pattern.description:
Glob pattern to protect tags. Examples: `v1.*` (protects tags starting with `v1.`), `*` (protects all tags).
Examples:
  "v1.*"
  "releases/stable/*"
  "*"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_TEAM
tools.title: Create a team
tools.description: Creates a new team in an organization, optionally with maintainers, repositories, specific privacy, notification settings, or a parent team; if `parent_team_id` is given, `privacy` must be 'closed'.

org.description:
Organization name where the team will be created (not case-sensitive).
Example: "my-github-org"

name.description:
Name of the new team.
Examples:
  "The A-Team"
  "Developers"

privacy.description:
Team privacy: 'secret' (visible to owners and members) or 'closed' (visible to all org members). Defaults to 'secret' for non-nested teams; must be 'closed' if `parent_team_id` is set.
Examples:
  "secret"
  "closed"

permission.description:
**Deprecated**. Default repository permission ('pull' for read access, 'push' for write access) for the team.
Examples:
  "pull"
  "push"

repo_names.description:
Repository full names (e.g., "org-name/repo-name") for team access; repositories must exist and be accessible to the organization.
Example: ["my-github-org/internal-project","my-github-org/another-repo"]

description.description:
Team's purpose or focus.
Example: "A team for frontend development projects."

maintainers.description:
GitHub user handles of organization members to be team maintainers; users must be organization members.
Example: ["octocat","gh-user123"]

parent_team_id.description:
ID of an existing team to be the parent, creating a nested team. If provided, new team `privacy` must be 'closed'.
Examples:
  "123"
  "456"

notification_setting.description:
Notification settings for @mentions: 'notifications_enabled' (members notified) or 'notifications_disabled' (no one notified). Default: 'notifications_enabled'.
Examples:
  "notifications_enabled"
  "notifications_disabled"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_TEMPORARY_PRIVATE_FORK
tools.title: Create a temporary private fork
tools.description: Creates a temporary private fork of the specified repository to address a security vulnerability, linking the fork to a GHSA ID that must be specifically associated with this repository; the fork may take up to 5 minutes to become accessible.

repo.description:
Name of the repository, without the `.git` extension; not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "linguist"
  "docs"

owner.description:
Account owner (username or organization) of the repository; not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github"

ghsa_id.description:
Identifier for the GitHub Security Advisory (e.g., GHSA-rfv9-x7w6-39px) that the fork will address.
Examples:
  "GHSA-rfv9-x7w6-39px"
  "GHSA- কাদের-abc1-2def"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_TREE
tools.title: Create a tree
tools.description: Creates a new Git tree object in a repository, defining file/directory structure by specifying tree entries, optionally building on a `base_tree` SHA; all provided SHAs must be valid.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.

tree.description:
Array of objects defining the tree structure. Each object (node) requires `path` (string), `mode` (string; e.g., '100644' file, '100755' executable, '040000' subdirectory/tree, '160000' submodule, '120000' symlink), and `type` (string: 'blob', 'tree', or 'commit'). For new/updated blobs, provide `content` (UTF-8 string). For existing objects or `tree`/`commit` types, provide `sha` (string). To delete, specify `path`, `mode`, `type`, and set `sha` to `null`.
Example: [{"content":"Hello World!","mode":"100644","path":"new_file.txt","type":"blob"},{"content":"# Markdown Content","mode":"100644","path":"subdir/another_file.md","type":"blob"}]

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

base_tree.description: SHA1 of an existing Git tree object to use as a base. If provided, its entries are combined with `tree` entries, where `tree` entries overwrite those from `base_tree` with the same path. Typically the SHA1 of the latest commit's tree for new branch changes. If omitted, the new tree is built from `tree` entries; files from the parent commit's tree not in `tree` are treated as deleted.

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_USER_PROJECT
tools.title: Create a user project
tools.description: Creates a new GitHub project board for the authenticated user to organize and track issues, pull requests, and notes.

body.description:
Body or description for the new project.
Examples:
  "A project to track Q3 deliverables."
  "Planning for the next product launch."
  "Collection of ideas and tasks for the website redesign."

name.description:
Name for the new project.
Examples:
  "My New Project"
  "Q3 Roadmap"
  "Website Redesign Ideas"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_WORKFLOW_DISPATCH_EVENT
tools.title: Create a workflow dispatch event
tools.description: Manually triggers a GitHub Actions workflow identified by `workflow_id` at a given `ref`, if the workflow is configured to accept `workflow_dispatch` events.

ref.description:
Git reference (branch or tag) for the workflow.
Examples:
  "main"
  "refs/heads/feature-branch"
  "refs/tags/v1.2.0"

repo.description:
Repository name, excluding the `.git` extension (case-insensitive).
Examples:
  "hello-world"
  "my-app-repository"

owner.description:
Owner of the repository (username or organization, case-insensitive).
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "my-organization"

inputs.description:
JSON string containing key-value inputs for the workflow, matching `on.workflow_dispatch.inputs` definitions (max 10); uses workflow defaults if omitted. Example: '{"actor": "mona", "environment": "production"}'
Examples:
  "{\"actor\": \"mona\", \"environment\": \"production\"}"
  "{\"version\": \"1.2.3\", \"skip_tests\": false, \"deploy_group\": \"canary\"}"

workflow_id.description:
Identifier of the workflow, which can be its numeric ID or filename (e.g., 'main.yml'); the GitHub API accepts either format.
Examples:
  1234567
  "build-and-deploy.yml"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_COMMIT_SIGNATURE_PROTECTION
tools.title: Create commit signature protection
tools.description: Enables commit signature protection for a specified branch, requiring all new commits to be signed.

repo.description:
The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.
Examples:
  "Hello-World"
  "linguist"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github"

branch.description:
The name of the branch. Cannot contain wildcard characters. To use wildcard characters in branch names, use [the GraphQL API](https://docs.github.com/graphql).
Examples:
  "main"
  "develop"
  "feature/new-login"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_DEPLOYMENT_PROTECTION_RULE
tools.title: Create a custom deployment protection rule on an environment

annotations.title: Create a custom deployment protection rule on an environment

tools.description: Enables a custom deployment protection rule for an existing environment in a repository by linking a configured GitHub App (via `integration_id`) to control deployments.

repo.description:
The name of the repository where the environment exists. Do not include the `.git` extension. This name is not case sensitive.
Examples:
  "my-awesome-app"
  "BackendService"

owner.description:
The GitHub username or organization name that owns the repository. This name is not case sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "MyOrganization"

integration_id.description: The unique identifier of the GitHub App that provides the custom deployment protection rule. This app must be installed and configured for the repository.

environment_name.description:
The name of the environment to which the protection rule will be applied. This name must be URL-encoded if it contains special characters (e.g., slashes `/` should be replaced with `%2F`).
Examples:
  "production"
  "staging%2Fuser-testing"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_JIT_RUNNER_CONFIG
tools.title: Create JIT runner config for repo

annotations.title: Create JIT runner config for repo

tools.description: Generates a temporary Just-In-Time (JIT) configuration for a new self-hosted GitHub Actions runner for a repository; any specified non-default `runner_group_id` must be an existing runner group accessible by the repository.

name.description:
The desired name for the new self-hosted runner.
Example: "my-jit-runner-1"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the '.git' extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
Example: "hello-world"

owner.description:
The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

labels.description:
A list of custom labels to assign to the runner. These labels help in targeting specific runners for jobs. Minimum items: 1. Maximum items: 100.
Example: ["self-hosted","linux","x64"]

work_folder.description:
The working directory for the runner, relative to its installation path. This is where job execution will take place.
Example: "_work_custom"

runner_group_id.description:
The unique identifier of the runner group to which the new runner will be assigned. Use 0 for the default group or the ID of a specific runner group.
Examples:
  1
  0

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_OR_UPDATE_A_CUSTOM_PROPERTY_FOR_AN_ORGANIZATION
tools.title: Create or update a custom property for an organization

annotations.title: Create or update a custom property for an organization

tools.description: Creates a new custom property (name must be unique for creation) or updates an existing one for an organization to define metadata for its repositories.

org.description:
The organization's unique identifier (case-insensitive).
Example: "my-org-name"

required.description: If true, property must be set for all repositories and `default_value` is mandatory.

value_type.description:
Data type of the custom property.
Examples:
  "string"
  "single_select"

description.description:
Explanation of the custom property's purpose.
Example: "Tracks the current status of a project."

default_value.description:
Default value if property isn't set. For `single_select` type, must be one of `allowed_values`.
Examples:
  "pending"
  "active"

allowed_values.description:
Ordered list of allowed values (up to 200). Required and non-empty if `value_type` is `single_select`.
Example: ["pending","active","completed","archived"]

custom_property_name.description:
Name of the custom property (case-sensitive).
Example: "project-status"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_OR_UPDATE_AN_ENVIRONMENT
tools.title: Create or update an environment
tools.description: Creates a new environment or updates an existing one in a GitHub repository, allowing configuration of deployment protection rules such as wait timers and reviewers; ensure `environment_name` is URL-encoded if it contains special characters.

repo.description:
Name of the repository, without the `.git` extension (not case-sensitive).
Examples:
  "hello-world"
  "dotfiles"

owner.description:
The username or organization name of the repository owner (not case-sensitive).
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github"

reviewers.description:
JSON string containing up to 6 users or teams allowed to review deployments. Reviewers need at least read access; one approval suffices. Each reviewer object requires `id` and `type` ('User' or 'Team'). Example: '[{"id": 4532, "type": "User"}]'
Examples:
  "[{\"id\": 4532, \"type\": \"User\"}]"
  "[{\"id\": 123, \"type\": \"Team\"}, {\"id\": 9876, \"type\": \"User\"}]"

wait_timer.description:
Time in minutes to delay a job after it's triggered (0-43,200, i.e., up to 30 days).
Examples:
  "0"
  "30"
  "1440"

environment_name.description:
Name of the environment. URL-encode if it contains special characters (e.g., '/' becomes '%2F').
Examples:
  "production"
  "staging%2Ffrontend"
  "dev-test"

prevent_self_review.description:
If true, prevents the user who triggered deployment from approving their own job.
Examples:
  "true"
  "false"

deployment__branch__policy__protected__b.description:
If true, only branches with existing protection rules can deploy; `deployment_branch_policy_custom_branch_policies` must then be false.
Examples:
  "true"
  "false"

deployment__branch__policy__custom__bran.description:
If true, deployment is restricted to branches matching custom name patterns; `deployment_branch_policy_protected_branches` must then be false.
Examples:
  "true"
  "false"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_OR_UPDATE_AN_ENVIRONMENT_SECRET
tools.title: Create or update an environment secret

annotations.title: Create or update an environment secret

tools.description: Creates or updates an environment secret with an `encrypted_value` that was encrypted using the public key identified by `key_id` for the specified environment.

repo.description:
The name of the repository. Not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "hello-world"
  "my-app-repository"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. Not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "my-organization"

key_id.description:
ID of the public key used for encryption, obtained from the 'Get an environment public key' GitHub API endpoint.
Example: "publicKeyIdentifierString12345"

secret_name.description:
Name of the secret. Case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "DATABASE_PASSWORD"
  "API_TOKEN"
  "DEPLOYMENT_KEY"

encrypted_value.description:
Value of the secret, encrypted with LibSodium using the public key obtained from the 'Get an environment public key' GitHub API endpoint for the target environment.
Example: "yourBase64EncodedEncryptedSecretValue"

environment_name.description:
Name of the environment. Case-sensitive; URL-encode special characters (e.g., `/` becomes `%2F`).

  "production"
  "staging%2Ffeature-branch"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_OR_UPDATE_AN_ORGANIZATION_SECRET
tools.title: Create or update an organization secret

annotations.title: Create or update an organization secret

org.description:
The organization name. The name is not case sensitive.

key_id.description:
ID of the public key (from 'Get an organization public key' endpoint) used for encryption. Required if `encrypted_value` is provided.
Example: "key_identifier_from_github_12345"

visibility.description:
Controls which repositories can access the secret. If 'selected', `selected_repository_ids` must be provided.
Examples:
  "all"
  "private"
  "selected"

secret_name.description:
The name of the secret.
Example: "ORGANIZATION_API_KEY"

encrypted_value.description:
Value for the secret, pre-encrypted using LibSodium with the organization's public key (obtained from 'Get an organization public key' endpoint). Required if creating a new secret or updating its value.
Example: "VGhpcyBpcyBhbiBleGFtcGxlIG9mIGFuIGVuY3J5cHRlZCB2YWx1ZQ=="

selected_repository_ids.description:
List of repository IDs that can access this secret. Required and only applicable when `visibility` is 'selected'.
Examples:
  "12345"
  "67890"
  "98761"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_OR_UPDATE_CUSTOM_PROPERTIES_FOR_AN_ORGANIZATION
tools.title: Create or update custom properties for an organization

annotations.title: Create or update custom properties for an organization

tools.description: Creates new custom property schemas or updates existing ones in bulk for a specified organization; each property definition must include `property_name` and `value_type`.

org.description:
The case-insensitive organization name.
Examples:
  "my-organization"
  "github"

properties.description:
Definitions for custom properties as a JSON string. Each must include a unique `property_name` (max 75 chars, no spaces) and `value_type`. Optional: `description`, `required`, `default_value`, `allowed_values` (for 'single_select' type).
Example: "[{\"property_name\": \"project-priority\", \"value_type\": \"single_select\", \"description\": \"Priority of the project\", \"required\": true, \"allowed_values\": [\"High\", \"Medium\", \"Low\"]}, {\"property_name\": \"environment\", \"value_type\": \"string\", \"description\": \"Deployment environment\"}]"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_OR_UPDATE_CUSTOM_PROPERTY_VALUES_FOR_A_REPOSITORY
tools.title: Create or update repository custom property values

annotations.title: Create or update repository custom property values

tools.description: Creates or updates up to 30 custom property values for a repository; custom properties must be predefined at the organization or repository level, and setting a property's value to `null` removes it.

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case sensitive.
Examples:
  "hello-world"
  "my-awesome-app"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. This name is not case sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "my-organization"

properties.description:
A list of custom property objects as a JSON string to create or update for the repository. Each object in the list must contain `property_name` (string identifying the custom property) and `value` (the value for the property, which can be a string, number, or a single-select option, matching the property's defined type). Example: '[{"property_name": "environment", "value": "production"}]'
Examples:
  "[{\"property_name\": \"environment\", \"value\": \"production\"}, {\"property_name\": \"project_status\", \"value\": \"active\"}]"
  "[{\"property_name\": \"data_sensitivity\", \"value\": \"high\"}, {\"property_name\": \"internal_tooling\", \"value\": true}]"
  "[{\"property_name\": \"needs_review_by\", \"value\": null}]"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_OR_UPDATE_FILE_CONTENTS
tools.title: Create or update file contents
tools.description: Creates a new file or updates an existing file in a GitHub repository; SHA can be provided to validate file updates, automatically fetched if not provided.

sha.description:
The blob SHA of the file being replaced. Can be provided to validate file updates, automatically fetched if not provided.
Example: "aa218f56b14c9653891f9e74264a383fa43fefbd"

path.description:
The full path to the file in the repository, including the filename and extension.
Examples:
  "README.md"
  "src/main.js"

repo.description:
The name of the repository (not case sensitive, without the `.git` extension).
Example: "Spoon-Knife"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository (not case sensitive).
Example: "octocat"

branch.description:
The branch name. Defaults to the repository’s default branch if omitted.
Examples:
  "main"
  "develop"

content.description:
The new file content, MUST BE Base64 encoded. For example, to upload the text 'Hello World', use 'SGVsbG8gV29ybGQ='.
Example: "SGVsbG8gV29ybGQ="

message.description:
The commit message for this file creation or update.
Examples:
  "feat: add new documentation"
  "docs: update README"

author__date.description:
Author's timestamp (ISO 8601 format). Defaults to committer's date if author details are provided but date is not.
Example: "2023-10-26T11:30:00Z"

author__name.description:
Author's name. If specified, `author_email` is also required. Defaults to committer details; if all committer/author details omitted, GitHub uses authenticated user.
Example: "Jane Smith"

author__email.description:
Author's email. If specified, `author_name` is also required. Defaults to committer details; if all committer/author details omitted, GitHub uses authenticated user.
Example: "jane.smith@example.com"

committer__date.description:
Committer's commit timestamp (ISO 8601 format). Defaults to current time if committer details are provided but date is not.
Example: "2023-10-26T12:00:00Z"

committer__name.description:
Committer's name. If specified, `committer_email` is also required. GitHub uses authenticated user if all committer/author details omitted.
Example: "John Doe"

committer__email.description:
Committer's email. If specified, `committer_name` is also required. GitHub uses authenticated user if all committer/author details omitted.
Example: "john.doe@example.com"

tools.name: GITHUB_CREATE_OR_UPDATE_REPO_SECRET_WITH_ENCRYPTED_VALUE
tools.title: Create or update repo secret with encrypted value

annotations.title: Create or update repo secret with encrypted value

tools.description: Creates or updates a Dependabot secret in a repository using an `encrypted_value` (pre-encrypted with LibSodium using the repository's Dependabot public key) and its corresponding `key_id`. This action allows you to securely manage secrets for a given repository, ensuring that sensitive data remains protected during the update process. By providing the encrypted value alongside the key ID, you can seamlessly maintain the necessary credentials for your repository's operations.

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "hello-world"
  "my-awesome-app"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository (e.g., a GitHub username or organization name). This name is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github"

key_id.description: The ID of the public key that was used to encrypt the secret value. This ID is retrieved from GitHub along with the public key via the 'Get a repository public key' endpoint for Dependabot secrets.

secret_name.description:
The name of the Dependabot secret to create or update.
Examples:
  "NPM_TOKEN"
  "DOCKER_REGISTRY_PASSWORD"

encrypted_value.description: Value for your secret. This value must be encrypted with LibSodium, using the public key retrieved from the GitHub API's 'Get a repository public key' endpoint for Dependabot secrets. The resulting encrypted string is typically Base64 encoded.

Example: "justice-league"

comment_number.description:
Unique number identifying the comment.
Example: "101"

discussion_number.description:
Unique number identifying the discussion.
Example: "42"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_ADMIN_BRANCH_PROTECTION
tools.title: Delete admin branch protection
tools.description: Removes admin enforcement from a protected branch (branch name cannot contain wildcard characters) in a repository.

repo.description: The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

branch.description: The name of the branch. Cannot contain wildcard characters.

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_FILE
tools.title: Delete a file
tools.description: Deletes a file by path from a GitHub repository, requiring a commit message and the file's current blob SHA to confirm the deletion.

sha.description:
Blob SHA of the file being deleted, required to ensure the correct file version.
Example: "d670460b4b4aece5915caf5c68d12f560a9fe3e4"

path.description:
Path to the file to be deleted within the repository.
Example: "notes/important.txt"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension (not case-sensitive).
Example: "Hello-World"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository (not case-sensitive).
Example: "octocat"

branch.description:
Branch from which the file will be deleted; defaults to the repository's default branch.
Examples:
  "main"
  "develop"

message.description:
Commit message for the deletion.
Example: "Delete old script"

author__name.description:
Name of the commit author for the deletion; defaults to the committer's name.
Example: "Mona Lisa"

author__email.description:
Email address of the commit author for the deletion; defaults to the committer's email.
Example: "mona@example.com"

committer__name.description:
Name of the user committing the deletion; defaults to the authenticated user's name.
Example: "Mona Lisa"

committer__email.description:
Email address of the user committing the deletion; defaults to the authenticated user's email.
Example: "mona@example.com"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_GIST
tools.title: Delete a gist
tools.description: Permanently deletes an existing GitHub gist, specified by its `gist_id`; this action is destructive and cannot be undone.

gist_id.description:
The unique identifier of the gist to be deleted.
Examples:
  "aa5a315d61ae9438b18d"
  "44f08d44327a40d2ab309a349bebec57"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_GIST_COMMENT
tools.title: Delete a gist comment
tools.description: Deletes a specific comment from a GitHub Gist using its `gist_id` and `comment_id`.

gist_id.description:
The unique identifier of the Gist from which the comment will be deleted.
Example: "aa5a315d61ae9438b18d79546350ada7"

comment_id.description:
The unique identifier of the comment to be deleted.
Example: "129642021"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_GITHUB_PAGES_SITE
tools.title: Delete a GitHub Pages site
tools.description: Deletes the GitHub Pages site for the specified repository; completes without error if no site is currently enabled.

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "Hello-World"
  "docs"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository (e.g., a user or organization). This name is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_LABEL
tools.title: Delete a label
tools.description: Permanently removes an existing label from a repository.

name.description:
The name of the label to delete. Label names are case-insensitive. If the label name contains spaces or special characters, ensure it is correctly URL-encoded (e.g., 'help wanted' becomes 'help%20wanted').
Examples:
  "bug"
  "enhancement"
  "help%20wanted"
  "good%20first%20issue"

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "Hello-World"
  "my-awesome-project"

owner.description:
The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "my-organization"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_MILESTONE
tools.title: Delete a milestone
tools.description: Deletes the specified milestone if it exists; this operation is idempotent, typically returning a 404 if the milestone is not found or already deleted.

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.

owner.description: The username or organization name that owns the repository. This name is not case-sensitive.

milestone_number.description: The unique number that identifies the milestone to be deleted.

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_APP_AUTHORIZATION
tools.title: Delete an app authorization
tools.description: Revokes a single, specific OAuth access token for an OAuth App, not all authorizations for the app.

client_id.description:
The client ID of the OAuth App for which the token grant is being revoked.
Example: "Iv1.1234567890abcdef"

access_token.description:
The specific OAuth access token to be revoked.
Example: "gho_aBcDeFgHiJkLmNoPqRsTuVwXyZ1234567890"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_APP_TOKEN
tools.title: Delete an app token
tools.description: Revokes an OAuth access token for a GitHub App, if the app exists and the token was issued to it.

client_id.description:
The client ID of the GitHub App.
Example: "Iv1.1234567890abcdef"

access_token.description:
The OAuth access token to be revoked.
Example: "gho_abcdef1234567890abcdef1234567890abcdef"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ARTIFACT
tools.title: Delete an artifact
tools.description: Deletes a GitHub artifact by its ID within a repository, typically resulting in an empty response (HTTP 204 No Content) on success.

repo.description:
Name of the repository, without the `.git` extension; not case-sensitive.
Example: "Hello-World"

owner.description:
Account owner of the repository (user or organization); not case-sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

artifact_id.description:
Unique ID of the artifact to delete.
Example: "123456789"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_AUTOLINK_REFERENCE_FROM_A_REPOSITORY
tools.title: Delete an autolink reference from a repository

annotations.title: Delete an autolink reference from a repository

tools.description: Deletes a specific autolink reference (which automatically links external resource IDs like JIRA-123 to URLs) from the specified repository.

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "hello-world"
  "docs"

owner.description:
The username or organization name that owns the repository. This is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github"

autolink_id.description:
The unique numerical identifier of the autolink reference to be deleted.
Examples:
  "1"
  "42"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_EMAIL_ADDRESS_FOR_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER
tools.title: Delete authenticated user email address
tools.description: Sends an empty request body to `DELETE /user/emails` to attempt deletion of user email addresses; the API typically requires specific emails, so outcome may vary.

emails.description: Array of email addresses to delete from the authenticated user account.

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ENVIRONMENT
tools.title: Delete an environment
tools.description: Deletes an existing deployment environment from an existing repository.

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This is not case sensitive.
Example: "hello-world"

owner.description:
The username or organization name that owns the repository. This is not case sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

environment_name.description:
The name of the environment to delete. The name must be URL encoded; for example, slashes (`/`) should be replaced with `%2F`.
Examples:
  "production"
  "staging%2FUS-West"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ENVIRONMENT_SECRET
tools.title: Delete an environment secret
tools.description: Deletes an existing and accessible secret from a specified environment within a GitHub repository, returning an empty dictionary on success or error details otherwise.

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "Spoon-Knife"
  "docs"

owner.description:
The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github"

secret_name.description:
The name of the secret to be deleted. GitHub stores and processes secret names as uppercase (e.g., `my_secret` becomes `MY_SECRET`).
Examples:
  "CI_TOKEN"
  "DATABASE_PASSWORD"

environment_name.description:
The name of the environment from which the secret will be deleted. This name must be URL-encoded if it contains special characters (e.g., slashes `/` should be replaced with `%2F`).
Examples:
  "production"
  "staging%2Fdeploy-group-1"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLE
tools.title: Delete an environment variable
tools.description: Deletes a named environment variable from a specified, existing environment within a GitHub repository.

name.description:
The name of the environment variable to delete.
Examples:
  "SECRET_TOKEN"
  "DB_PASSWORD"

repo.description:
The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.
Examples:
  "hello-world"
  "api-client"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "my-github-org"

environment_name.description:
The name of the environment. Must be URL-encoded if it contains special characters (e.g., slashes `/` should be `%2F`).
Examples:
  "production"
  "staging%2Fbeta"
  "dev-user%2Fbranch-name"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ISSUE_COMMENT
tools.title: Delete an issue comment
tools.description: Permanently deletes a specific comment by its ID from an issue or pull request, if the repository exists and the comment ID is valid.

repo.description:
Name of the repository, without the `.git` extension (case-insensitive).
Example: "Spoon-Knife"

owner.description:
Username of the account owning the repository (case-insensitive).
Example: "octocat"

comment_id.description:
Unique identifier of the comment to delete.
Example: "42"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ISSUE_COMMENT_REACTION
tools.title: Delete an issue comment reaction
tools.description: Deletes a reaction from an issue comment in a repository; the repository, comment, and reaction must exist.

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "Spoon-Knife"
  "docs"

owner.description:
The username of the account that owns the repository. This is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github"

comment_id.description:
The unique numeric identifier for the issue comment from which the reaction will be deleted.
Examples:
  12345
  67890

reaction_id.description:
The unique numeric identifier for the reaction to be deleted.
Examples:
  1
  2

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ISSUE_REACTION
tools.title: Delete an issue reaction
tools.description: Permanently removes a specific reaction from an issue in a GitHub repository.

repo.description:
The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.
Example: "Spoon-Knife"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

reaction_id.description:
The unique identifier of the reaction to be deleted.
Example: "1"

issue_number.description:
The unique number identifying the issue from which the reaction will be deleted.
Example: "1347"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ORGANIZATION
tools.title: Delete an organization
tools.description: Deletes a GitHub organization and its repositories; this is a destructive action and the organization name will be unavailable for reuse for approximately 90 days.

org.description:
The unique name of the organization to be deleted. This name is not case-sensitive.
Example: "my-github-org"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ORGANIZATION_SECRET
tools.title: Delete an organization secret
tools.description: Permanently deletes a secret from a GitHub organization, making it inaccessible to GitHub Actions workflows or other tools.

org.description:
The name of the organization. This name is not case-sensitive.
Example: "octo-org"

secret_name.description:
The name of the secret to be deleted.
Example: "CI_DEPLOY_KEY"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ORGANIZATION_VARIABLE
tools.title: Delete an organization variable
tools.description: Deletes a named GitHub Actions variable from a specified organization.

org.description:
The name of the organization. This parameter is not case-sensitive.
Example: "my-org-name"

name.description:
The name of the organization variable to delete. This parameter is not case-sensitive.
Example: "MY_VARIABLE"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ORGANIZATION_WEBHOOK
tools.title: Delete an organization webhook
tools.description: Deletes a specific webhook, identified by `hook_id`, from an existing organization.

org.description:
The name of the organization. This field is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "github"
  "my-company-org"

hook_id.description:
The unique identifier of the webhook. This ID can be retrieved from the `X-GitHub-Hook-ID` header in a webhook delivery or by listing organization webhooks.
Examples:
  123456789
  987654321

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_PACKAGE_FOR_AN_ORGANIZATION
tools.title: Delete a package for an organization

annotations.title: Delete a package for an organization

tools.description: Deletes a specific package in an organization; cannot delete public packages with over 5,000 downloads.

org.description:
Name of the organization owning the package (not case-sensitive).
Examples:
  "octo-org"
  "my-company"

package_name.description:
Unique name of the package to be deleted.
Examples:
  "my-package"
  "your-library-name"

package_type.description:
Type of the package to be deleted. Packages in GitHub's Gradle registry have type `maven`. Docker images in GitHub's Container registry (`ghcr.io`) have type `container`. Use type `docker` for images previously in GitHub's Docker registry (`docker.pkg.github.com`), even if migrated to the Container registry.
Examples:
  "npm"
  "maven"
  "rubygems"
  "docker"
  "nuget"
  "container"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_PACKAGE_FOR_A_USER
tools.title: Delete a package for a user

annotations.title: Delete a package for a user

tools.description: Deletes a package owned by the specified user, requiring admin permissions for the authenticated user; deletion of public packages with over 5,000 downloads may require GitHub support.

username.description:
The GitHub username of the account that owns the package.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "your-username"

package_name.description:
The unique name of the package to be deleted.
Examples:
  "my-private-package"
  "internal-tool-cli"

package_type.description:
Ecosystem of the package. Packages in GitHub's Gradle registry use `maven`. Docker images pushed to GitHub's Container registry (`ghcr.io`) use `container`. The `docker` type can find images from the old Docker registry (`docker.pkg.github.com`), even if migrated.
Examples:
  "npm"
  "maven"
  "rubygems"
  "docker"
  "nuget"
  "container"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_PACKAGE_FOR_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER
tools.title: Delete a package for the authenticated user

annotations.title: Delete a package for the authenticated user

tools.description: Permanently deletes a specific package owned by the authenticated user; public packages downloaded over 5,000 times cannot be deleted via this API.

package_name.description:
The unique name of the package to be deleted.
Examples:
  "my-package-name"
  "your-software-project"

package_type.description:
Specifies package type. Note: GitHub Gradle packages are 'maven'; ghcr.io images are 'container'; 'docker' type helps find images migrated from docker.pkg.github.com.
Examples:
  "npm"
  "maven"
  "docker"
  "container"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_PACKAGE_VERSION_FOR_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER
tools.title: Delete a package version for the authenticated user

annotations.title: Delete a package version for the authenticated user

tools.description: Deletes an existing package version associated with the authenticated user.

package_name.description:
The unique name of the package.
Examples:
  "my-company-package"
  "internal-tool"

package_type.description:
Type of the package. E.g., `maven` for GitHub Gradle registry, `container` for `ghcr.io` images. The `docker` type covers images from `docker.pkg.github.com` (including migrated ones).
Examples:
  "npm"
  "maven"
  "rubygems"
  "docker"
  "nuget"
  "container"

package_version_id.description:
The unique numeric identifier of the specific package version to be deleted.
Examples:
  "102345"
  "7890"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_PENDING_REVIEW_FOR_A_PULL_REQUEST
tools.title: Delete a pending review for a pull request

annotations.title: Delete a pending review for a pull request

tools.description: Deletes a pending (unsubmitted) review from a pull request; this is only possible if the review has not yet been submitted.

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.

  "hello-world"
  "octo-repo"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. This name is not case-sensitive.
Examples:
  "octocat"
  "github-linguist"

review_id.description:
The unique identifier of the pending review to be deleted.
Examples:
  "80"
  "42"

pull_number.description:
The number that identifies the pull request.
Examples:
  "1347"
  "100"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_PROJECT

tools.description: Deletes the GitHub project specified by `project_id` if the project exists and the projects feature is enabled for its repository or organization; a successful deletion results in a 204 No Content response.

project_id.description: The unique identifier of the project to be deleted.

tools.title: Delete a project card
tools.description: Deletes a project card from a GitHub 'Project (classic)'; this operation is idempotent.

card_id.description:
The unique numerical identifier of the project card to be deleted.

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_PROJECT_COLUMN
tools.title: Delete a project column
tools.description: Deletes a project column by its ID from a GitHub project (classic); this is a destructive operation.

column_id.description:
The unique identifier of the project column to be deleted.

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_PULL_REQUEST_COMMENT_REACTION
tools.title: Delete a pull request comment reaction

annotations.title: Delete a pull request comment reaction

Name of the repository, without the `.git` extension; not case-sensitive.

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_REFERENCE
tools.title: Delete a reference
tools.description: Deletes a Git reference from a repository; 'ref' must be fully qualified (e.g., 'refs/heads/branch' or 'refs/tags/tag').

Full path of the Git reference to delete (e.g., 'refs/heads/main' or 'refs/tags/v1.0.0'). GitHub auto-prefixes 'refs/heads/' for branches if 'refs/' is omitted; 'refs/tags/' prefix is mandatory for tags.
Examples:

repo.description:
The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case sensitive.
Example: "Spoon-Knife"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. This name is not case sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_RELEASE

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_SELF_HOSTED_RUNNER_FROM_AN_ORGANIZATION
tools.title: Delete a self hosted runner from an organization

annotations.title: Delete a self hosted runner from an organization

tools.description: Deletes an existing and registered self-hosted runner from an organization, typically returning 204 No Content on success.

org.description:
Organization name (not case-sensitive).
Examples:
  "octo-org"
  "my-company"

runner_id.description:
Unique ID of the self-hosted runner to remove (obtainable by listing organization runners).
Examples:
  "5"
  "42"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_SELF_HOSTED_RUNNER_FROM_A_REPOSITORY
tools.title: Delete a self hosted runner from a repository

annotations.title: Delete a self hosted runner from a repository

tools.description: Removes a specific self-hosted runner (by `runner_id`) from a repository, if registered there; this is idempotent.

repo.description:
The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.
Example: "hello-world"

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.
Example: "octocat"

runner_id.description:
Unique identifier of the self-hosted runner.
Examples:
  "123"
  "456"

tools.name: GITHUB_DELETE_A_TAG_PROTECTION_STATE_FOR_A_REPOSITORY
tools.title: Delete a tag protection state for a repository

annotations.title: Delete a tag protection state for a repository

tools.description: Permanently deletes a specific tag protection rule, identified by its ID, from the given repository.

repo.description:
The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.

owner.description:
The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

tag_protection_id.description:
